THE FIRST HOPKINS LACROSSE TEAM.
The continued success of the Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team, and the adding of
another intercollegiate championship to its already long list must be a matter of
pride to every I Iopkins man. In no other branch of athletics has she ever attained
superiority, hut in lacrosse she must be reckoned the equal of any team in the
country. The writer has been asked to say a few words on the history of the
game at Hopkins. 1 had the honor, with three others, to organize the first
team 1 Iol)k ins had, the others being Morrison, Roszell and Cone, whose magnificent goal keeping has never been excelled in this country and probably never
will be. We ,were freshmen then in "'87," but had had our trying out and coaching
on the best lacrosse team America has ever produced. I refer, of course, to. the
famous "Druids." It was slow work getting recruits, the baseball men tried
in every way to discourage us. No money was given from the treasury, and
our only aid was the moral support given by Dr. Renouf, to whom lacrosse at
Hopkins will ever owe a great debt of gratitude. C. Riggs, Princeton's "87,"
was taking a P. G. course with us and he was elected captain as he had captained his Princeton team the previous year.
At . last a team was gotten together, and a game arranged with a strong
local team, "'The Pattersons."
The line-up was as follows:

A word to you,
it make you young again to see yourselves lined up for play? Do you remember
how we dressed in fear and trembling, how, we suffered from that physiological
condition which so often precedes any contest ? Can you see old George Foy as
he pats every one on the back encouraging every one? "Lacrosse at Hopkins
is at stake to-day, defeat means no more lacrosse." The game is on now and
work. work, -work is the motto, five. minutes, ten, fifteen, no goal Yet, and then one,
two, three, four Hopkins in (-Mick succession. Oh the courage that came with
them, you who play know what it is, no one else can understand. The game
goes on, is finished, Hopkins has won, ti to 2. Not only has Hopkins won at

lacrosse, hut lacrosse has on at Hopkins; and from that (lay they have plodded
and worked and bettered the game until we have such a team as represents us today.
Hopkins has turned out some of the best individual players of the country.
I have only to mention such names as Cone, T. Penniman, Janney, Fitzgerald,
addren, Tyler, Mitchell, and Abercrombie, with a score more. We can only say
to those who shall represent our Alma Mater in future years, keep up the high
standard set for you. Play fast, play hard, play to win, but over and above all
these PLAY FAIR.
Faithfully yours,
BKRW1CK BRUCE LANIP:R, A. B., "'90."

ATHLETICS IN THE FAR EAST.

ONSTANTINOPLE is the meeting of the Orient and the Occident. It is
really an Oriental city, which the Occident is seeking to enter. The Orient stands for conservatism and inactivity, while activity and change characteize the Occident. This contrast applies to all spheres of life—physical, mental and spiritual. Amid these conditions one would not look for much enthusiasm and activity in the athletic line ; for people generally move as though one
day were a thousand years; which is quite a contrast with America, where people
try to crowd a thousand years into one day.
On the shores of the Bosphorus-6 miles from Constantinople—we have an
American institution, Robert College ; founded by Americans, manned largely
by Americans, the object of the founders being to put a little Christian leaven
(of the American brand) into this part of the world with the hope that it may
leaven the whole lump. The trustees, recognizing the great value of the physical development in this problem, requested the author to come out and do what
he could in this direction. Incidentally he has been teaching a little biology.
But first a few words about the college in general. There are about three
hundred students, about equally divided between the collegiate and preparatory
departments. Twelve nationalities are represented, though the Greeks, Americans, and Bulgarians predominate. All of these are Christians, though unfortunately only nominally so, in a majority of cases. in point of age the students
are about two years younger than Hopkins undergraduates ; while the course of
study does not differ very materially from that of the University ; the large amount
of time devoted to language, and the lack of thoroughness being the chief differences.
Physically the students are both undersized and poorly developed. Lack
of exercise, poor and insufficient food and exercise, use of tobacco appear to be
the chief factors to account for this condition. Here it is quite common even for
the ladies of first rank to smoke, the cigarette being their favorite.

C

THE NEWS LETTER.

3

A careful physical examination is made of each student, including a number of measurements and test of strength. These are recorded and filed. A
duplicate is given to each student, on which are written recommendations, which
are calculated to counteract existing defects.
We have a gymnasium, or more properly speaking, a room in which there is
some standard gymnastic apparatus, which the boys used last winter with a good
deal of zest. Exercise is at present required of all the preparatory students ; but
it is optional for the college boys. At the close of the season a very creditable
gymnastic exhibition was given, the work on the parallel bars and the general class
drill being especially good. Wrestling was one of the novel features to the peoPle. An appropriation of $10,000 has been made for the erecting of a gymnasium,
which will be begun this summer.
As for athletics, football and field sports are the favorites. There is but little
interest in baseball. The association football is the four employed. The boys
. play it with a good deal of vim, though team work is usually lacking, each one
wishing to distinguish himself by brilliant plays. The national spirit manifests
itself. Quite frequently a Greek will take the slightest provocation to twist the
nose of the Bulgarian, while the American and the Turk sometimes choose a
match game as a place to settle some difference.
The boys are now training for field-day. This year we are to have two sets
of games—handicap and scratch. There is usually a very good audience, both
in point of quality and size, to witness these contests. Below is appended a list
of records of the college. This year many of the records will probably be lowered,
for already in practice about one--half of them have been smashed.
The present records of Robert College are:

My best wishes for my alma pater (Princeton being my alma mater) in all

THE 1903 LACROSSE SEASON.

HE Johns Hojikins Lacrosse Team—LCollegiate Champions of the United
States. The above record speaks for itself, and is one of which the
students of the University may justly feel elated. The high standard set by our
lacrosse teams in former years, has been fully maintained by the team during
the past season. The coaches deserve great credit for the manner in which the
new men were developed to fill the vacancies occasioned by last year's graduation.
The loss was considerable, being confined entirely to old and experienced players.
In the reappearance of Fred. Foster, who played in the championship games of
1899, and 1900, the team was especially fortunate. Of the older members of the
team, all showed marked improvement in their play over previous years, while the
work of the new men was most creditable and of the highest order.
Owing to sifting and trying out of the new material, it was hard to draw
much of a line as to the ability of the team until the Hobart game, when it was seen
that our boys were playing the kind of game which wins championships
The new Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, consisting of Johns Hopkins.
Swarthmore, Lehigh and Stevens, was successful in every way. All the members
of the League worked in harmony and accord.
The new league gained a signal success in that none of its teams were defeated by those of the Liniversity League which consists of Harvard, Cornell,
Pennsylvania and Columbia.
Without exception, the teams of the Intercollegiate Association were detidedly stronger this season than last, while some of the teams of the University
League also showed better form, notably Pennsylvania. It is to be hoped that this
increase in strength will continue, as it will tend to establish the game- on a firmer
basis amongst the colleges of this country.
I Acrosse is an ideal college sport. and the increasing popularity in the sections where it is played, is doing much to stimulate the game in other localities.
In the past year, a number of new teams have been started, especially amongst
the preparatory schools. This movement is being encouraged by the colloges who
hope to reap benefit in the future. The lack of men., trained in lacrosse before
entering college, has been a great drawback to the advancement of the game
in the Lnited States. The average college lacrosse player has learned the game
about the time he is graduated, simply because at least several years are required
to get the knack of handling his stick and to master the fine points of the game.
If this preliminary work is learned in the preparatory school, it may be predicted
that the time will come when the American college team will successfully cope in
lacrosse with the college teams of our Canadian neighbors.

1.IE close of the Twenty-seventh Academic Year of the Johns Hopkins University marks a time to pause and reflect on the work of the past year.
This task is a most agreeable one, since all departments of the University have registered a steady growth.. The high position of Johns Hopkins as the
first University in the land has been fully maintained. The University is free
from all financial difficulty, and Homewood, the goal of our ambitions, draws
nearer every day.
In other departments besides scholarship there has been the same encouraging growth. As in former years "Hopkins Spirit" has secured victories over
institutions numbering many times the l'niversity's student body. The football season though short was a successful one. The track team has had a year
of unprecedented success. Not only have many new records been made but the
meets held by the University have set a high standard. "Intercollegiate Champions
of the United States" is the proud title held once again by the lacrosse team. The
musical teams scored fresh triumpbs. Most important of all, the season was a
financial success. The iI90:3 "Hullabaloo" is one of. the best year books ever
issued, and compares very favorably with the best in the country.

THE NEWS LETTER.

'7

Whether or not TH1 Nms-Llirriiiz has kept pace with the other student departments, it is not for us to say here. The two boards have been hampered by
the fact that not an the editorships were filled, but they have enjoyed the work,
and feel that they have derived considerable experience that will be valuable in
years to come. If an increased subscription list is an indication of commendation, the board knows that its efforts have not been in vain.

HE NEWS-LETTER takes a special pride in the two leading articles in this
issue. Dr. Berwick Lanier, '90, and Dr. C. W. Ottley, M. D., '99, did
•much to advance athletics while they were at the University, and., their
interest in Hopkins's success has not abated with the passing years. Dr. Lanier Was
a member of the first Varsity lacrosse team, and he has continued to follow the
game from year to year, and though various changes in the style of play have
taken place since the first Hopkins team, yet Dr. Lanier has kept abreast of these,
and has always cheerfully given the team whatever aid he could. Dr. ()aim
from the time he entered the Me.dical School until his graduation four years ago,
was one of the stars of the track team, and, indeed, one of the best athletes who
ever brought success to the "I hack and Blue." The splendid work that he is doing in far away Turkey is a matter of pride to his many friends. That he is just
as enthusiastic an athlete as ever is proved by his account of how he has got the
Turk to take an interest in track and field sports.

SATURDAY'S GAME WITH TORONTO.
Saturday afternoon, at Oriole Park, the University lacrosse team will meet
the champion Toronto team, in the last and greatest game of the season. The
Canadians, who hold the intercollegiate championship of the Dominion, are coining to Baltimore prepared for the hardest sort of a contest. The Varsity team
has .kept in practice since the game with the Crescents, though the I. Tniversity examinations have been a great strain upon the men. Some of the faults and misplays
which were prominent in the Crescent game will hardly occur again, as the coaches
have given special attention to these.. The players realize that their abilities will
be tested to the utmost, and are training accordingly. Toronto's team numbers
only three of last year's twelve, but nearly all the other players have been associated with sonic well known lacrosse team before they entered the University of
Toronto.
According to present indications the record breaking crowd at last year's game
\vill be surpassed on Saturday. Mayor McLane has promised to attend. Gov.
Smith, and the other State officials will also be present. The senior class will attend in a body.

SENIOR CLASS WEEK PROGRAMME.

t HE 1903 class festivities begin this noon when the usual senior procession
will take place. A tour of the l'niversity building will be made, with
the customary halts, and speeches. Later in the day the class will enjoy
a boating party on the bay. The Programme for the remainder of the week is
as follows:
Friday, June 5—A lawn party at Homewood, giveri by the trustees to the
friends of the University. Thirty of the seniors will act as assistants to the reception committee. At 9 P. M. Dean Edward H. Griffin will give his annual reception to the graduating class. He will receive this season in the Johns Hopkins
Club.
Saturday, June 6—The class will attend the Toronto lacrosse game in a
body. That night a reception and dinner will be given to the Canadian players.
Mr. H. K. T()otle of the senior class will preside, and addresses will be made,
among others, by President Remsen, President Abercrombie of the Athletic Association, Mr. Mackdermott of the physical training department, and Captains
Iflanck, Straus and Hoffman.
Sunday, June 7—Dean Griffin will preach the baccalaureate sermon in Levering Hall at 11 A. M. Hitherto the sermon has been preached in one of the city
churches. All University men are invited to attend.
Monday, June 8—President Remsen will entertain the graduating class and
a few friends at luncheon in the Donovan room of McCoy Hall. The senior
"Prom" will make Monday night the banner night Of the festival week. This will
begin at 9 o'clock in the large assembly room of McCoy Hall. A programme
including 21 dances has been arranged for the "Prom." About 300 people are
expected to attend, and supper will be served late ;.n Lie
I evening.
Tuesday, June 9—Commencement exercises at I P. M., and University reception following that night.

THE TRACK SEASON.

HE outlook for the track and field was, as usual, very poor when college
opened last autumn, for we certainly had sustained severe losses. Weedon,
one of our cracks, both in the jumps and in the sprints, had graduated, and
the same might be said of Bill Hoffman, one of the best middle distance men in
college, and a member of the Relay Team, and Riggs, another Relay man, had to
give up on account of medical work.. These three and some others were the
principal losses, and it only left two men on the Relay, and the team .in general

t

in poor condition.
karly in the fall the raw freshman material was gotten out, with hopes that
a few good ones could be found to take the place of those who we lost, and also
we sent. a circular letter to many of the incoming medical men. As a result of
this letter, such men as Freese, 'Helmholtz and Sladen responded.
On the first of J ai wary the regular season began, and for some time it looked
as if the team would never get in trim, but finally it did, and the undergraduate
members showed up every well in the Inter-Class Meet, which was held in the

18

THE NEWS LETTER.

Cage in the last week of January. The Seniors won in a walk-over, but very
few points separated the Juniors and the Freshmen. This meet was an innovation at the University, and I hope it will be continued in the years to come.
Now when this was over, we had two weeks to prepare for the 13. A. C.
indoor Meet, which was held on February 14th, at 8 P. M. This was a handicap
meet, and Hopkins on the majority of points. Helmholtz won the dash and
broad jump in fine style, and Lawson took first place in the shot and second in
the high jump, first place in the latter event to Scholl. We took a number of
seconds and thirds, and from a point of view of points scored we certainly got our
share.
The next meet was Georgetown's annual affair, which took place on March
7th, and we won the event which we most desired, that is the Relay race with
Villa Nova, and the team showed up very well, running in the following order:
Stone, Capt. Hoffman, Freese and England. Each one of these men gained considerably on his opponent. Besides the Relay, Freeze took second in the hurdle.
On March 28th came the Hopkins Meet at the Armory, and from every point
of view it was a great success. Duffy, the Georgetown champion, ran an exhibition 35 yard dash, and did it in 4 seconds, breaking the state record. Everything was Hopkins that night and the men deserve much credit as they had
handicaps, etc., to overcome. Tootle took both the dashes and the 440 in fine style,
England was third in the mile, Hoffman second in the half-mile, and Freeze first
in the hurdle. Altogether the team did splendid work.
The next question was the Pennsylvania Relay Races. En years previous
we had run the Maryland colleges, and had beaten them regularly, so this year
when we had a chance to go higher up in classes, we took it, and we never did a
better thing, for instead of only going up One class, we were put in the Middle
States Championship Class. This meant that we should have to run ; so hard
training began and continued right along till the time to go to Philadelphia arrived.
This was a hard race, and we ft)nght hard for it, but missed first place by a few
yards, being beaten by Bucknell in 3.39. The time was faster than the figures
indicated, as the track was very slow. The team was composed of Freese, Hoffman, England and Tootle, With Stone as substitute.
Now we arrive at the grand climax of the year, the Dual Meet with Virginia.
This meet had been worked up since January, and was considered by all to be the
greatest movement in track athletics that the University ever had. This memorable event took place at Electric Park on May 7th. The Virginia team was in
fine trim and ours the same. Tootle did splendid work in both the 100 and 220,
winning in 10 sec. and 22 sec. respectively.
In the mile two J. H. U. Freshmen showed to the front. Morse heating
Campbell by about 6 inches. In the jumps Scholl and Pessagno won points in
fine form, and Freese took the hurdles and Emig the pole vault. The 110 was
the hardest race of the day, and England who was counted on to win was ill, but
gamely fought on till he fell, after this it was between Shelton, of Virginia, and
Hoffman, J. H. U., the former winning by about 2 feet in iS1.l sec. The half mile
and shot went to Virginia, but Stone did fine work in the latter. The whole meet

THE NEWS LETTER.

19

was a great success, and Johns Ilopkins won it handily by 55 points to 33. This
practically ended the season, except for the men who went to the Intercollegiates.
In the latter, the men just missed qualifying.
In summing up the year on a whole I think it was _a great success, and too
much credit can not be given to the men who have done their best for Johns I lopkins, and I hope that future teams will be as successful and earnest in their
work as the team of 1903.
R. CuRzoN Hovvm AN, JR.,
Capt. Track and Field Team.

A SALLY FROM OUR ALLEY.

(With apologies to the late Lord Tennyson.)
Broke, broke, broke!
i\ly last nickel gone, by gee!
And I would that my lips dared utter
The words that occur to me.
Ah well for our worthy Dean
That he frowns on this gambling- play ;
Ah well for the moral young man
Who belongs to the Y. M. C. A.
But this losing game goes on
Every morning down by the "gym ;'
And 0 for a turn in my beastly luck
Or a hoo-doo to help me win.
Broke, broke, broke!
Every pocket is empty, by gee!
For the nickel pitched wild, and the nickel turned tail
Can never come back to me.
W. B. C.

THE FIRST HOPKINS LACROSSE TEAM.
The continued success of the Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team, and the adding of
another intercollegiate championship to its already long list must be a matter of
pride to every I Iopkins man. In no other branch of athletics has she ever attained
superiority, hut in lacrosse she must be reckoned the equal of any team in the
country. The writer has been asked to say a few words on the history of the
game at Hopkins. 1 had the honor, with three others, to organize the first
team 1 Iol)k ins had, the others being Morrison, Roszell and Cone, whose magnificent goal keeping has never been excelled in this country and probably never
will be. We ,were freshmen then in "'87," but had had our trying out and coaching
on the best lacrosse team America has ever produced. I refer, of course, to. the
famous "Druids." It was slow work getting recruits, the baseball men tried
in every way to discourage us. No money was given from the treasury, and
our only aid was the moral support given by Dr. Renouf, to whom lacrosse at
Hopkins will ever owe a great debt of gratitude. C. Riggs, Princeton's "87,"
was taking a P. G. course with us and he was elected captain as he had captained his Princeton team the previous year.
At . last a team was gotten together, and a game arranged with a strong
local team, "'The Pattersons."

how we dressed in fear and trembling, how, we suffered from that physiological

he pats every one on the back encouraging every one? "Lacrosse at Hopkins
is at stake to-day, defeat means no more lacrosse." The game is on now and

ATHLETICS IN THE FAR EAST.

ONSTANTINOPLE is the meeting of the Orient and the Occident. It is
really an Oriental city, which the Occident is seeking to enter. The Orient stands for conservatism and inactivity, while activity and change characteize the Occident. This contrast applies to all spheres of life—physical, mental and spiritual. Amid these conditions one would not look for much enthusiasm and activity in the athletic line ; for people generally move as though one
day were a thousand years; which is quite a contrast with America, where people
try to crowd a thousand years into one day.
On the shores of the Bosphorus-6 miles from Constantinople—we have an
American institution, Robert College ; founded by Americans, manned largely
by Americans, the object of the founders being to put a little Christian leaven
(of the American brand) into this part of the world with the hope that it may
leaven the whole lump. The trustees, recognizing the great value of the physical development in this problem, requested the author to come out and do what
he could in this direction. Incidentally he has been teaching a little biology.
But first a few words about the college in general. There are about three
hundred students, about equally divided between the collegiate and preparatory
departments. Twelve nationalities are represented, though the Greeks, Americans, and Bulgarians predominate. All of these are Christians, though unfortunately only nominally so, in a majority of cases. in point of age the students
are about two years younger than Hopkins undergraduates ; while the course of
study does not differ very materially from that of the University ; the large amount
of time devoted to language, and the lack of thoroughness being the chief differences.
Physically the students are both undersized and poorly developed. Lack
of exercise, poor and insufficient food and exercise, use of tobacco appear to be
the chief factors to account for this condition. Here it is quite common even for
the ladies of first rank to smoke, the cigarette being their favorite.

C

THE NEWS LETTER.

3

A careful physical examination is made of each student, including a number of measurements and test of strength. These are recorded and filed. A
duplicate is given to each student, on which are written recommendations, which
are calculated to counteract existing defects.
We have a gymnasium, or more properly speaking, a room in which there is
some standard gymnastic apparatus, which the boys used last winter with a good
deal of zest. Exercise is at present required of all the preparatory students ; but
it is optional for the college boys. At the close of the season a very creditable
gymnastic exhibition was given, the work on the parallel bars and the general class
drill being especially good. Wrestling was one of the novel features to the peoPle. An appropriation of $10,000 has been made for the erecting of a gymnasium,
which will be begun this summer.
As for athletics, football and field sports are the favorites. There is but little
interest in baseball. The association football is the four employed. The boys
. play it with a good deal of vim, though team work is usually lacking, each one
wishing to distinguish himself by brilliant plays. The national spirit manifests
itself. Quite frequently a Greek will take the slightest provocation to twist the
nose of the Bulgarian, while the American and the Turk sometimes choose a
match game as a place to settle some difference.
The boys are now training for field-day. This year we are to have two sets
of games—handicap and scratch. There is usually a very good audience, both
in point of quality and size, to witness these contests. Below is appended a list
of records of the college. This year many of the records will probably be lowered,
for already in practice about one--half of them have been smashed.
The present records of Robert College are:

Intercollegiate meets for the present seem to be out of the question ; our
nearest possible competitor being four days distant.
My best wishes for my alma pater (Princeton being my alma mater) in all
lines especially in the realm of athletics.
Yours sincerely,
CHAS. W. OTTUW, M. D., '99.

THE 1903 LACROSSE SEASON.

HE Johns Hojikins Lacrosse Team—LCollegiate Champions of the United
States. The above record speaks for itself, and is one of which the
students of the University may justly feel elated. The high standard set by our
lacrosse teams in former years, has been fully maintained by the team during
the past season. The coaches deserve great credit for the manner in which the
new men were developed to fill the vacancies occasioned by last year's graduation.
The loss was considerable, being confined entirely to old and experienced players.
In the reappearance of Fred. Foster, who played in the championship games of
1899, and 1900, the team was especially fortunate. Of the older members of the
team, all showed marked improvement in their play over previous years, while the
work of the new men was most creditable and of the highest order.
Owing to sifting and trying out of the new material, it was hard to draw
much of a line as to the ability of the team until the Hobart game, when it was seen
that our boys were playing the kind of game which wins championships
The new Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association, consisting of Johns Hopkins.
Swarthmore, Lehigh and Stevens, was successful in every way. All the members
of the League worked in harmony and accord.
The new league gained a signal success in that none of its teams were defeated by those of the Liniversity League which consists of Harvard, Cornell,
Pennsylvania and Columbia.
Without exception, the teams of the Intercollegiate Association were detidedly stronger this season than last, while some of the teams of the University
League also showed better form, notably Pennsylvania. It is to be hoped that this
increase in strength will continue, as it will tend to establish the game- on a firmer
basis amongst the colleges of this country.
I Acrosse is an ideal college sport. and the increasing popularity in the sections where it is played, is doing much to stimulate the game in other localities.
In the past year, a number of new teams have been started, especially amongst
the preparatory schools. This movement is being encouraged by the colloges who
hope to reap benefit in the future. The lack of men., trained in lacrosse before
entering college, has been a great drawback to the advancement of the game
in the Lnited States. The average college lacrosse player has learned the game
about the time he is graduated, simply because at least several years are required
to get the knack of handling his stick and to master the fine points of the game.
If this preliminary work is learned in the preparatory school, it may be predicted
that the time will come when the American college team will successfully cope in
lacrosse with the college teams of our Canadian neighbors.

1.IE close of the Twenty-seventh Academic Year of the Johns Hopkins University marks a time to pause and reflect on the work of the past year.
This task is a most agreeable one, since all departments of the University have registered a steady growth.. The high position of Johns Hopkins as the
first University in the land has been fully maintained. The University is free
from all financial difficulty, and Homewood, the goal of our ambitions, draws
nearer every day.
In other departments besides scholarship there has been the same encouraging growth. As in former years "Hopkins Spirit" has secured victories over
institutions numbering many times the l'niversity's student body. The football season though short was a successful one. The track team has had a year
of unprecedented success. Not only have many new records been made but the
meets held by the University have set a high standard. "Intercollegiate Champions
of the United States" is the proud title held once again by the lacrosse team. The
musical teams scored fresh triumpbs. Most important of all, the season was a
financial success. The iI90:3 "Hullabaloo" is one of. the best year books ever
issued, and compares very favorably with the best in the country.

THE NEWS LETTER.

'7

Whether or not TH1 Nms-Llirriiiz has kept pace with the other student departments, it is not for us to say here. The two boards have been hampered by
the fact that not an the editorships were filled, but they have enjoyed the work,
and feel that they have derived considerable experience that will be valuable in
years to come. If an increased subscription list is an indication of commendation, the board knows that its efforts have not been in vain.

HE NEWS-LETTER takes a special pride in the two leading articles in this
issue. Dr. Berwick Lanier, '90, and Dr. C. W. Ottley, M. D., '99, did
•much to advance athletics while they were at the University, and., their
interest in Hopkins's success has not abated with the passing years. Dr. Lanier Was
a member of the first Varsity lacrosse team, and he has continued to follow the
game from year to year, and though various changes in the style of play have
taken place since the first Hopkins team, yet Dr. Lanier has kept abreast of these,
and has always cheerfully given the team whatever aid he could. Dr. ()aim
from the time he entered the Me.dical School until his graduation four years ago,
was one of the stars of the track team, and, indeed, one of the best athletes who
ever brought success to the "I hack and Blue." The splendid work that he is doing in far away Turkey is a matter of pride to his many friends. That he is just
as enthusiastic an athlete as ever is proved by his account of how he has got the
Turk to take an interest in track and field sports.

SATURDAY'S GAME WITH TORONTO.
Saturday afternoon, at Oriole Park, the University lacrosse team will meet
the champion Toronto team, in the last and greatest game of the season. The
Canadians, who hold the intercollegiate championship of the Dominion, are coining to Baltimore prepared for the hardest sort of a contest. The Varsity team
has .kept in practice since the game with the Crescents, though the I. Tniversity examinations have been a great strain upon the men. Some of the faults and misplays
which were prominent in the Crescent game will hardly occur again, as the coaches
have given special attention to these.. The players realize that their abilities will
be tested to the utmost, and are training accordingly. Toronto's team numbers
only three of last year's twelve, but nearly all the other players have been associated with sonic well known lacrosse team before they entered the University of
Toronto.
According to present indications the record breaking crowd at last year's game
\vill be surpassed on Saturday. Mayor McLane has promised to attend. Gov.
Smith, and the other State officials will also be present. The senior class will attend in a body.

SENIOR CLASS WEEK PROGRAMME.

t HE 1903 class festivities begin this noon when the usual senior procession
will take place. A tour of the l'niversity building will be made, with
the customary halts, and speeches. Later in the day the class will enjoy
a boating party on the bay. The Programme for the remainder of the week is
as follows:
Friday, June 5—A lawn party at Homewood, giveri by the trustees to the
friends of the University. Thirty of the seniors will act as assistants to the reception committee. At 9 P. M. Dean Edward H. Griffin will give his annual reception to the graduating class. He will receive this season in the Johns Hopkins
Club.
Saturday, June 6—The class will attend the Toronto lacrosse game in a
body. That night a reception and dinner will be given to the Canadian players.
Mr. H. K. T()otle of the senior class will preside, and addresses will be made,
among others, by President Remsen, President Abercrombie of the Athletic Association, Mr. Mackdermott of the physical training department, and Captains
Iflanck, Straus and Hoffman.
Sunday, June 7—Dean Griffin will preach the baccalaureate sermon in Levering Hall at 11 A. M. Hitherto the sermon has been preached in one of the city
churches. All University men are invited to attend.
Monday, June 8—President Remsen will entertain the graduating class and
a few friends at luncheon in the Donovan room of McCoy Hall. The senior
"Prom" will make Monday night the banner night Of the festival week. This will
begin at 9 o'clock in the large assembly room of McCoy Hall. A programme
including 21 dances has been arranged for the "Prom." About 300 people are
expected to attend, and supper will be served late ;.n Lie
I evening.
Tuesday, June 9—Commencement exercises at I P. M., and University reception following that night.
The class committee which has arranged this programme is made up of
Messrs. R. C. Hoffman (chairman), W. H. Matthai, W. M. Hunly, W. S. Bird,
H. N. Baetjer, H. W..Plaggemeyer and L. M. Tough.

THE TRACK SEASON.

HE outlook for the track and field was, as usual, very poor when college
opened last autumn, for we certainly had sustained severe losses. Weedon,
one of our cracks, both in the jumps and in the sprints, had graduated, and
the same might be said of Bill Hoffman, one of the best middle distance men in
college, and a member of the Relay Team, and Riggs, another Relay man, had to
give up on account of medical work.. These three and some others were the
principal losses, and it only left two men on the Relay, and the team .in general

t

in poor condition.
karly in the fall the raw freshman material was gotten out, with hopes that
a few good ones could be found to take the place of those who we lost, and also
we sent. a circular letter to many of the incoming medical men. As a result of
this letter, such men as Freese, 'Helmholtz and Sladen responded.
On the first of J ai wary the regular season began, and for some time it looked
as if the team would never get in trim, but finally it did, and the undergraduate
members showed up every well in the Inter-Class Meet, which was held in the

18

THE NEWS LETTER.

Cage in the last week of January. The Seniors won in a walk-over, but very
few points separated the Juniors and the Freshmen. This meet was an innovation at the University, and I hope it will be continued in the years to come.
Now when this was over, we had two weeks to prepare for the 13. A. C.
indoor Meet, which was held on February 14th, at 8 P. M. This was a handicap
meet, and Hopkins on the majority of points. Helmholtz won the dash and
broad jump in fine style, and Lawson took first place in the shot and second in
the high jump, first place in the latter event to Scholl. We took a number of
seconds and thirds, and from a point of view of points scored we certainly got our
share.
The next meet was Georgetown's annual affair, which took place on March
7th, and we won the event which we most desired, that is the Relay race with
Villa Nova, and the team showed up very well, running in the following order:
Stone, Capt. Hoffman, Freese and England. Each one of these men gained considerably on his opponent. Besides the Relay, Freeze took second in the hurdle.
On March 28th came the Hopkins Meet at the Armory, and from every point
of view it was a great success. Duffy, the Georgetown champion, ran an exhibition 35 yard dash, and did it in 4 seconds, breaking the state record. Everything was Hopkins that night and the men deserve much credit as they had
handicaps, etc., to overcome. Tootle took both the dashes and the 440 in fine style,
England was third in the mile, Hoffman second in the half-mile, and Freeze first
in the hurdle. Altogether the team did splendid work.
The next question was the Pennsylvania Relay Races. En years previous
we had run the Maryland colleges, and had beaten them regularly, so this year
when we had a chance to go higher up in classes, we took it, and we never did a
better thing, for instead of only going up One class, we were put in the Middle
States Championship Class. This meant that we should have to run ; so hard
training began and continued right along till the time to go to Philadelphia arrived.
This was a hard race, and we ft)nght hard for it, but missed first place by a few
yards, being beaten by Bucknell in 3.39. The time was faster than the figures
indicated, as the track was very slow. The team was composed of Freese, Hoffman, England and Tootle, With Stone as substitute.
Now we arrive at the grand climax of the year, the Dual Meet with Virginia.
This meet had been worked up since January, and was considered by all to be the
greatest movement in track athletics that the University ever had. This memorable event took place at Electric Park on May 7th. The Virginia team was in
fine trim and ours the same. Tootle did splendid work in both the 100 and 220,
winning in 10 sec. and 22 sec. respectively.
In the mile two J. H. U. Freshmen showed to the front. Morse heating
Campbell by about 6 inches. In the jumps Scholl and Pessagno won points in
fine form, and Freese took the hurdles and Emig the pole vault. The 110 was
the hardest race of the day, and England who was counted on to win was ill, but
gamely fought on till he fell, after this it was between Shelton, of Virginia, and
Hoffman, J. H. U., the former winning by about 2 feet in iS1.l sec. The half mile
and shot went to Virginia, but Stone did fine work in the latter. The whole meet

THE NEWS LETTER.

19

was a great success, and Johns Ilopkins won it handily by 55 points to 33. This
practically ended the season, except for the men who went to the Intercollegiates.
In the latter, the men just missed qualifying.
In summing up the year on a whole I think it was _a great success, and too
much credit can not be given to the men who have done their best for Johns I lopkins, and I hope that future teams will be as successful and earnest in their
work as the team of 1903.
R. CuRzoN Hovvm AN, JR.,
Capt. Track and Field Team.

A SALLY FROM OUR ALLEY.

(With apologies to the late Lord Tennyson.)
Broke, broke, broke!
i\ly last nickel gone, by gee!
And I would that my lips dared utter
The words that occur to me.
Ah well for our worthy Dean
That he frowns on this gambling- play ;
Ah well for the moral young man
Who belongs to the Y. M. C. A.
But this losing game goes on
Every morning down by the "gym ;'
And 0 for a turn in my beastly luck
Or a hoo-doo to help me win.
Broke, broke, broke!
Every pocket is empty, by gee!
For the nickel pitched wild, and the nickel turned tail
Can never come back to me.
W. B. C.
